facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 202 and 203 of 1965 are appeals from the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1961 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeals Nos. 55 and 56 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 202 and 203 of 1965. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1961 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeals Nos. 55 and 56 of 1959.

facts.text: The appellant is a limited Company carrying on transport business in South Arcot District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited Company carrying on transport business in South Arcot District. M. A. Khader, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965, holds 13 shares and his brother, M. A. Jabbar, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965, holds 163 shares in the Company.

facts.text: M. A. Khader holds 13 shares in the Company and is respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: M. A. Khader, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965, holds 13 shares and his brother, M. A. Jabbar, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965, holds 163 shares in the Company.

facts.text: M. A. Jabbar holds 163 shares in the Company and is respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965 and brother of M. A. Khader.

anchor.surface_text: M. A. Khader, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1965, holds 13 shares and his brother, M. A. Jabbar, the companytesting respondent in Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1965, holds 163 shares in the Company.

facts.text: On January 2, 1957, the board of directors of the Company passed a resolution calling the unpaid amount of Rs. 25/- on each share.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1957, the board of directors of the Company passed a resolution calling the unpaid amount of Rs. 25/- on each share. On January 3, 1957, a call numberice was issued to the shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957.

facts.text: On January 3, 1957, a call notice was issued to the shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1957, a call numberice was issued to the shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957. The call numberices were duly served on the companytesting respondents.

facts.text: The call notices were duly served on the contesting respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The call numberices were duly served on the companytesting respondents. As the call monies remained unpaid, the Company issued the 68 5 following numberice dated January 20, 1957 to the respondents under Art. 29

facts.text: As the call monies remained unpaid, the Company issued notice dated January 20, 1957 to the respondents under Art. 29.

anchor.surface_text: As the call monies remained unpaid, the Company issued the 68 5 following numberice dated January 20, 1957 to the respondents under Art. 29 Sir, As the call amount of the balance of Rs. 25/- for every share held by you remains unpaid

facts.text: The notice dated January 20, 1957 called upon respondents to pay Rs.25/- per share at registered office by January 30, 1957 together with interest at six per cent and expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Sir, As the call amount of the balance of Rs. 25/- for every share held by you remains unpaid in respect of the numberice dated 3rd January 1957 issued in pursuance of the resolution of the Board, I hereby issue this numberice calling upon you to pay the called amount at the registered office of the Company on or before Wednesday the 30th January 1957, together with interest at six per cent and any expenses that might have accrued by reason of such number-payment.

facts.text: The notice dated January 20, 1957 was signed by A. R. Hassain Khan Managing Director.

anchor.surface_text: By order of the Board  Signed  A. R. Hassain Khan Managing Director. In spite of this numberice, the respondents did number pay the call monies, and on February 11, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by them.

facts.text: In spite of the notice dated January 20, 1957, the respondents did not pay the call monies.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this numberice, the respondents did number pay the call monies, and on February 11, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by them.

facts.text: On February 11, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this numberice, the respondents did number pay the call monies, and on February 11, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by them. On November 8, 1957, the respondents filed two separate applications under s. 155 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956

facts.text: On November 8, 1957, the respondents filed two separate applications under s. 155 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 in the High Court of Madras praying that the forfeitures be set aside and rectifications be made in the share register.

anchor.surface_text: On November 8, 1957, the respondents filed two separate applications under s. 155 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 in the High Court of Madras praying that the forfeitures be set aside and the necessary rectifications be made in the share register of the Company.

facts.text: Ramachandra Ayyar, J. allowed the applications and passed consequential orders for rectification of the registers.

anchor.surface_text: Ramachandra Ayyar, J. allowed the applications, and passed companyditional orders for rectification of the registers and his decision was affirmed by the appellate Court.

facts.text: The decision of Ramachandra Ayyar J. was affirmed by the appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ramachandra Ayyar, J. allowed the applications, and passed companyditional orders for rectification of the registers and his decision was affirmed by the appellate Court. The Courts below held that in the absence of Particulars of interest and expenses, the numberice dated January 20, 1957 was defective

facts.text: The Courts below held that the notice dated January 20, 1957 was defective in the absence of particulars of interest and expenses and the forfeiture is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below held that in the absence of Particulars of interest and expenses, the numberice dated January 20, 1957 was defective and the forfeiture is invalid.

facts.text: The Company appeals to this Court by on a certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Company number appeals to this Court by on a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: On January 18, 1957, M. A. Jabbar, M. A. Khadir and other shareholders filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in the Madras High Court praying for reliefs under ss. 402 and 237 and obtained an interim order directing stay of collection of monies pursuant to the notice dated January 3, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1957, M. A. Jabbar, M. A. Khadir and other shareholders filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in the Madras High Court praying for reliefs under ss. 402 and 237 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956, and obtained an interim order directing stay of companylection of monies pursuant to the numberice dated January 3. 1957.

facts.text: The stay order was communicated to the directors on January 21, 1957 after the notice dated January 20, 1957 was issued.

anchor.surface_text: The stay order was companymunicated to the directors on January 21, 1957 after the numberice of the intended forfeiture dated January 20, 1957 was issued.

facts.text: On January 30, 1957, the Court passed a modified interim order restraining the forfeiture of the shares, and directed M. A. Jabbar to pay the call money into Court within one week.

anchor.surface_text: On January 30, 1957, the Court passed a modified interim order restraining the forfeiture of the shares, and directed M. A. Jabbar to pay the call money into Court within one week. The call money was number paid into Court, and on February 8, 1957, the Court vacated the stay order.

facts.text: The call money was not paid into Court.

anchor.surface_text: The call money was number paid into Court, and on February 8, 1957, the Court vacated the stay order. Application No. 119 of 1957 was eventually dismissed on April 10, 1957.

facts.text: On February 8, 1957, the Court vacated the stay order.

anchor.surface_text: The call money was number paid into Court, and on February 8, 1957, the Court vacated the stay order. Application No. 119 of 1957 was eventually dismissed on April 10, 1957.

facts.text: Application No. 119 of 1957 was eventually dismissed on April 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Application No. 119 of 1957 was eventually dismissed on April 10, 1957.

facts.text: The High Court held that the notice dated January 20, 1957 is defective in respect of the demand for expenses as the amount was not disclosed.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the numberice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the number- payment was number disclosed.

facts.text: The respondents are trade rivals of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant points out that the respondents are the trade rivals of the appellant and are anxious to cripple its affairs, and the appellate Court recorded the finding that the respondents were acting mala fide

Articles 29 and 30 of the Articles of Association of the Company read The notice shall name a future day, not being less than seven days from the service of the notice, on or before which such call or other money and all interest and expenses that may have accrued by reason of such non-payment are to be paid and the place where payment is to be made, the place so named being either registered office of the Company or the principal place where payments are usually made payable and shall state that in the event of non-payment at or before the time and at the place appointed the share in respect of which such payment is due, will be liable to be forfeited. If the requirements of any such notice as aforesaid be not complied with, any share in respect of which such notice has been given may, at any time thereafter before payment of all money due thereon with interest and expenses, be forfeited by a resolution of the Directors to that effect.

concepts.interpretation: Notice under Art. 29 must specify a future day not less than 7 days, place of payment, demand call money, interest, expenses, and warn of forfeiture; compliance is condition precedent to valid forfeiture under Art. 30.

concepts.interpretation: Allows rectification of share register if name omitted without sufficient cause; issue is whether omission without sufficient cause, not whether shareholder has sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: Section 155 1 a ii of the Indian Companies Act allows rectification of the share register if the name of any person after having been entered in the register is, without sufficient cause, omitted therefrom.

concepts.interpretation: Court has jurisdiction where forfeiture invalid leads to omission without sufficient cause.

issues.text: Whether the notice dated January 20, 1957 under Article 29 was defective in respect of the demand for expenses due to non-disclosure of the amount of expenses?

issues.text: Whether a proper notice under Article 29 is a condition precedent to valid forfeiture under Article 30?

anchor.surface_text: A proper numberice under Art. 29 is a companydition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the numberice under Art. 29 is defective, and the companydition precedent is number companyplied with.

issues.text: Whether the forfeiture of shares was invalid due to the defective notice under Article 29?

anchor.surface_text: The slight defect in the numberice invalidates it and is fatal to the forfeiture. The Courts below, therefore, rightly declared that the forfeiture was invalid.

issues.text: Whether the names of the respondents were omitted from the share register without sufficient cause, attracting jurisdiction under Section 155(1)(a)(ii) of the Companies Act, 1956?
Whether the contention regarding invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 was open to the respondents despite absence of specific pleading?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant companytended that the point as to the invalidity of the numberice dated January 20, 1957 was number open to the respondents in the absence of any pleading on this point.

Whether the relief under Section 155 is discretionary and should be refused in the circumstances of the case?
Whether the respondents came with clean hands entitling the court to refuse relief under the equity maxim?

holdings.text: The notice dated January 20, 1957 is defective in respect of the demand for expenses as the amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the notice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed. The respondents were not informed how much they should pay on account of the expenses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 29 requires notice to disclose sufficient information on amount due including expenses to enable payment and avoid forfeiture; object is to inform shareholder precisely.

holdings.text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture under Art. 30.

anchor.surface_text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 29 specifies requirements for notice; non-compliance prevents valid forfeiture under Art. 30.

holdings.text: The forfeiture of shares is invalid due to the defective notice under Art. 29.

anchor.surface_text: The slight defect in the notice invalidates it and is fatal to the forfeiture. The Courts below, therefore, rightly declared that the forfeiture was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defect in condition precedent notice (expenses not quantified) renders forfeiture invalid.

holdings.text: Omission of shareholder's name from register due to invalid forfeiture is without sufficient cause, attracting jurisdiction under s.155(1)(a)(ii) for rectification.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid forfeiture provides no sufficient cause for omission; s.155 focuses on company's cause for omission, not shareholder's.

holdings.text: The contention of invalidity of the notice dated January 20, 1957 was open to respondents despite absence of specific pleading.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Point raised in arguments without objection; pleadings could have been amended.

holdings.text: Respondents did not waive or abandon right to challenge forfeiture by proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that (1) by reason of the aforesaid proceedings the respondents waived and abandoned their right to challenge the forfeiture... We find nothing... from which we can infer a waiver or abandonment...

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence in proceedings infers waiver of challenge to notice and forfeiture validity.

holdings.text: The court order dated January 30, 1957 did not substitute a fresh notice under Art. 29.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court order restraining forfeiture and directing payment into court does not fulfill Art. 29 notice requirements.

holdings.text: Relief under s.155 should not be refused where forfeiture invalid; discretion not arbitrary.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Simple matter suitable for summary jurisdiction under s.155; cannot refuse where entitlement established.

holdings.text: Clean hands maxim inapplicable; respondents asserting legal right, not equity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Relief under s.155 enforces legal right post-invalid forfeiture; unrelated misconduct irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the High Court that the notice is defective in respect of the demand for expenses. The amount of expenses incurred by the Company by reason of the non-payment was not disclosed. The respondents were not informed how much they should pay on account of the expenses.
In the result, the appeals are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding that proper notice is condition precedent directly addresses the issue whether it is a condition precedent.

anchor.surface_text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with.
In the result, the appeals are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding of invalid forfeiture addresses issue of invalidity due to defective notice

anchor.surface_text: The slight defect in the notice invalidates it and is fatal to the forfeiture. The Courts below, therefore, rightly declared that the forfeiture was invalid.
In the result, the appeals are dismissed.
